author: Eric Helms
title: Smart Contract Audit Token SCAT DAO
description: Consumers have trouble trusting DeFi Dapps with their money. Dapps can be audited, but how can you trust a paid auditor to act impartially?

assessments.note: while this proposal will bring an element of competition for DeFi projects through third party audits, it does not in itself provide more DeFi use in Cardano.

The proposal consists of an independent, self funding auditing DApp. 
The notion of creating audits without being dependent on customer funding would contribute to audit quality and stimulate community investments in DeFi on Cardano. 
A clear definition of success seems to be missing. (How many audits a week are you aiming to perform?)

While there remains some discussion about the suitability of this proposal in the current challenge, I am satisfied that the explanation given by the proposer is valid. Perhaps the query that does get generated after reading through the proposal is that a lot more work needs to be completed to get the ball rolling.
Great idea. Doesn't really meet the goal of the project to encourage the building of new DeFi solutions. This could significantly help build user confidence in the DeFi ecosystem.

The problem and solution described are within the scope of the challenge. No metrics have been described to measure the impact of the proposal on the challenge, which makes the success and impact assessment subjective. The goals set are in line with the challenge, as they would allow the audit of dapps and this would bring more security to the DeFi ecosystem.
Yes, security audit are important for DeFi. However, nothing demonstrates that audits cannot be trusted today.

The proposer has relevant experience in the auditing business in current US business practices, however it isn't clear how the blockchain specific functions of the audit will be addressed. In addition, the project claims that funding will come from a treasury of it's token but doesn't include a decription on how the initial funding of the treasury will take place. This has significant implications dependent on the methodology used, and it isn't addressed.

The author is experienced in Fortune 500 company audits, yet has no relevant experience to write the DApp. It is critical to onboard developers to write this DApp. As of now, there is no clarity in who would perform this task. I suggest using the seek-tags to reach the right people for this.

The author has certainly spent some time developing the proposal and the current team meet certain criteria experience wise. They also acknowledge the critical need for devs that can handle the significant coding aspect of the project.  At the time of this assessment I could not find if this has progressed. In light of such it may have been wise to further frame the audit governance and submit a smaller first stage proposal.
Proposer has the skillset to develop (LinkedIn profile to confirm would be good). It would be good to have an operating and financing plan going forward. How much will it cost per project to audit.

The team describes experience in IT and finance audits, but it is not clear whether these experiences include smart contract audits and what the team's expertise with Plutus is. As one of the goals is to create a utility token it is important to understand the team's experience and aptitude in developing a tokenomics model, as the feasibility of the proposal will depend on the utility of the token.

It is important to say that costs with audit of DeFi protocols are extremely high due to the need for staff with great technical knowledge, so that the DAO has people qualified to carry out the audits. The absence of a robust tokenomics model hinders the project's feasiblity. The dependence of revenue on a possibility of interest (in protocols that do not yet exist at Cardano) of a token that does not yet have a robust model of tokenomics brings a lot of uncertainty about the viability and sustainability of the project.

There are details on the budget allocation.

Some risks are not being taken into account, such as:
1- The dependence on protocols to generate yield (protocols and dapps that do not yet exist at Cardano)
2- There is no guarantee that the SCAT token will be listed in dapps as an asset to generate yield.
3- Auditors will receive competitive rewards for auditing smart contracts, but this is based on a tokenomics model that is not yet well structured and may not be enough.
4 - The audit of projects by DAO does not remove the risks of fraud and collusion. There is no mention of a reputation model for auditors that can mitigate this problem.
Security audits are expensive, and it's unclear how the passive income would be sufficient to fund the requested code reviews.

The proposal doesn't include an estimate on how large the problem of bad-actors are in this space, doesn't include an estimate on how many projects could use auditing, and doesn't include an estimate on how market capitalization on the SCAT token.  Would individuals want to hold the token? what would prompt individuals to fund SCAT over the current practice of 'wait and see' if someone else falls into a trap mentality.

There is a lot of information already present in the text, however, there are still some aspects that need some work. There is important information lacking involving visibility and how the project would make sure that the audits would get read and where they would be published. It needs some kind of marketing to get known by the community. There is no concrete risk assessment included.

The proposal is well written, received interest from the community and seems a valid concept. The information was satisfactory and inclusive. This included the not inconsiderable risk/task of finding suitable developers for the coding aspects of the project.
Initial plan easy to audit. Measurable KPI's going forward would be good. Is each project to be audited initially on launch, or repeatedly? What will be the funding requirement going forward?

There is clarity in the description of the problem, but the solution still needs to be more detailed, especially in relation to the tokenomics model.

There is no information on the team's experience with Plutus and with smart contract audits (audit in finance and IT was mentioned). There are details on budget allocation and the roadmap. There are no metrics or KPIs.

solution: A DAO which will have audit projects chosen by the community and funded entirely through their treasury with zero conflict of interest.
experience: Eric Helms is a CPA who has spent the last 10 years in audit with Big 4 public audit experience and Fortune 500 internal audit experience.
